title: Queen's secret wish came true with 'inappropriate' photo - sparking 'disbelief'
text:

The Queen has posed for thousands of official photographs during her time on the throne to mark and celebrate a variety of occasions.

But despite being one of the most photographed people in the world, there was one type of shot she had always wanted to appear in by was told it wasn't appropaite.

Speaking to her dresser and friend Angela Kelly, the Monarch revealed she would love to be snapped in a more informal pose, such as standing with her hands in her pockets.

The Queen Mother and her advisors told her not to do it, but Angela had a thoughtful idea when she was writing her first book Dressing the Queen.

Writing in her new book The Other Side of the Coin, she says: "I wondered if I might have a wonderful opportunity to make the Queen's wish come true."

(Image: PA)

She nervously asked the Queen if she would "do her a favour" and pose with her hands in her pockets for an image in the book, reports Hello!.

She said: "The Queen looked at me in amazement as I asked whether she knew the implications of the photographs."

She said yes almost straight away and Angela got to work arranging the shoot.

When the day came photographer Barry Jeffery started speaking to the Queen about what he was hoping to get, but Angela says the Queen "politely" put her hand up and said she knew how she was doing it.

(Image: Getty Images)

Angela writes: "Her Majesty took her position in front of the lens and started striking a series of poses, slipping her hands in and out of her pockets and placing them onto her hips, mimicking the stances of a professional model.

"I stood by in disbelief - The Queen was a natural Barry and I felt we were experiencing something really special: a moment never to be repeated."

However, when it came to putting the book together some of the more candid shots were not used.

According to Angela, the Royal Collection were concerned the photos would "bring the Monarchy down", so weren't allowed to go in.

Angela has shared a number of other secrets in her book, which she wrote with approval from the Queen, including the bizarre story behind the Royal Family's christening gown .

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

The intricate lace and satin piece is an exact replica of one which has been worn by all royal babies since 1841.

In 2004 the Queen decided the original had become too fragile to use, so asked for a new one to be made for future generations.

Her dressmaker and friend Angela Kelly was given the important task, and reveals in her new book that she got the colour just right dying it in Yorkshire Tea.

Accompanied by dresser Barbara Buckfield, Angela travelled to Italy to find the perfect lace for the new gown carrying the priceless original in her handbag.

(Image: REUTERS)

She writes: "Together, we sourced lace to complement that being made in Italy, and to make sure it looks authentic we dyed it in Yorkshire tea (the strongest, as we all know).

"We placed each piece of lace in a small bown, from the Dressers' kitchen, filled with cool water and a tea bag, and left it for about five minute, checking regluaraly until the colour was perfect."

Angela showed the Queen the gown at each stage of the process, which took about nine months.

"Her Maesty was very interested to see how it was developing."
description: The Queen told her dresser and friend Angela Kelly about her secret wish years ago, so when the talented designer saw an opportunity to make it come true she couldn't resist
